articles.headline: Outraged in Private, Many C.E.O.s Fear the Wrath of the President
articles.snippet: The chief executives of Merck, Under Armour and Intel had the courage to resign as a presidential adviser, but others have been less forceful.
articles.abstract: The chief executives of Merck, Under Armour and Intel had the courage to resign as a presidential adviser, but others have been less forceful.
articles.lead_paragraph: At what point do the C.E.O.s of the largest companies in the United States tell President Trump that enough is enough?

articles.headline: Under Armour and Intel C.E.O.s Follow Merck Chief, Quitting Panel in Rebuke to Trump
articles.snippet: Three corporate leaders stepped down from a White House advisory group after President Trump equivocated in his initial remarks on racially motivated violence in Charlottesville, Va.
articles.abstract: Three corporate leaders stepped down from a White House advisory group after President Trump equivocated in his initial remarks on racially motivated violence in Charlottesville, Va.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three chief executives from top American companies resigned from a presidential business council on Monday following President Trump’s tepid initial response to a violent weekend in Charlottesville, Va.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Bannon in Limbo as Trump Faces Growing Calls for the Strategist’s Ouster
articles.snippet: The president’s delay in denouncing neo-Nazis in Charlottesville has put new pressure on Stephen K. Bannon, who ran the Breitbart website.
articles.abstract: The president’s delay in denouncing neo-Nazis in Charlottesville has put new pressure on Stephen K. Bannon, who ran the Breitbart website.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch has repeatedly urged President Trump to fire him. Anthony Scaramucci, the president’s former communications director, thrashed him on television as a white nationalist. Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, the national security adviser, refused to even say he could work with him.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Success Can’t Ease Headaches for HBO
articles.snippet: HBO should be riding high with the success of “Game of Thrones” but criticism over a coming series and a hack of its internal computer system have cast a pall.
articles.abstract: HBO should be riding high with the success of “Game of Thrones” but criticism over a coming series and a hack of its internal computer system have cast a pall.

articles.headline: Following ‘Fire and Fury,’ Trump Looks to Ease Tensions in Asia
articles.snippet: President Trump used unusually restrained language in opening a trade offensive against China as his military advisers tamped down talk of war with North Korea.
articles.abstract: President Trump used unusually restrained language in opening a trade offensive against China as his military advisers tamped down talk of war with North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, following days of bellicose threats toward North Korea and jitters about a looming trade war with China, moved on several fronts Monday to ease tensions in East Asia, after making the region a flash point for his administration.

articles.headline: Far Right Plans Its Next Moves With a New Energy
articles.snippet: Some white supremacists and right-wing extremists were making arrangements to appear at future marches, and others were planning to run for office.
articles.abstract: Some white supremacists and right-wing extremists were making arrangements to appear at future marches, and others were planning to run for office.
articles.lead_paragraph: The white supremacists and right-wing extremists who came together over the weekend in Charlottesville, Va., are now headed home, many of them ready and energized, they said, to set their sights on bigger prizes.

articles.headline: Ferraris and Opera Were Urgent, but Grenfell Tower Risks Went Unheeded
articles.snippet: Councilors in London’s Kensington and Chelsea borough, home to some of the city’s wealthiest and poorest residents, are accused of catering to the wealthy and ignoring the poor.
articles.abstract: Councilors in London’s Kensington and Chelsea borough, home to some of the city’s wealthiest and poorest residents, are accused of catering to the wealthy and ignoring the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Ferraris were driving people batty in affluent South Kensington. Drivers revved their engines and ripped past Harrods. Residents were already irritated by the dust and noise from superrich neighbors building underground swimming pools and cinemas. Now came complaints about Middle Eastern “types” drag racing at night.

articles.headline: One U.S. Factory Goes Global, While Trump Shrinks the World
articles.snippet: As the administration renegotiates Nafta, a fan manufacturer in Kentucky worries that its business could be hurt by rising impediments to trade.
articles.abstract: As the administration renegotiates Nafta, a fan manufacturer in Kentucky worries that its business could be hurt by rising impediments to trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Never mind the refrain that the American factory is supposedly a dinosaur in the age of globalization.

articles.headline: It’s the Economy, Democrats, but Inequality Is Not the Issue
articles.snippet: The party risks tacking too far to the left when more centrist solutions could provide what many voters yearn for: a decent job with a secure future.
articles.abstract: The party risks tacking too far to the left when more centrist solutions could provide what many voters yearn for: a decent job with a secure future.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo. — Is income inequality the defining challenge of our time? Bernie Sanders thinks so. He ran for president as inequality’s most ardent foe. So does Elizabeth Warren, the other champion of the Democratic Party’s left.
